If a small group of living beings (a small population) is separated from the main population, from which it originates (e.g. if it crosses a mountain range or a river, or if it settles on a new island, so that it cannot easily return), they often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so that the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor, rather than what it used to be.
The original population has not changed at all. It still needs the same adaptations as before.
With time, the new population adapts to its new environment, and then it looks less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years, two populations look so different that they can no longer be assigned to the same species.
We call this process speciation, which simply means the emergence of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from the technological push or the technological imperative to the strict sense that human destiny is determined by a logic that is linked to scientific laws and its manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general views. On the one hand, that the development of technology follows a path that is largely outside the influence of cultural or political factors, and on the other hand, that technology itself has effects on societies that are more inherent than socially determined.
It can be said that the automobile is unavoidably linked to the development of roads.
However, a nationwide road network for only a small number of cars is not economically viable. Therefore, new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of car ownership.

The widespread ownership of cars also leads to an increase in the number of accidents on the roads, which in turn leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to repair damaged bodies.

Insects can destroy food, cause irritations or even allergic reactions, poison or transmit diseases.
Infectious diseases as such or dangerous animals that can injure or kill people by force are not classified as vermin.
Tax-free shopping is the possibility to buy goods that are exempt from taxes and consumption taxes at certain places.
Travellers whose destination country has a high tax rate can sometimes save a considerable amount of money, especially on products such as alcoholic drinks and tobacco.
The section between Point Marion and Fairmount on the highway Buffalo-Pittsburgh is probably the greatest driving challenge, because it often leads through remote, uninhabited terrain.
If you're not used to driving on country roads, be careful: steep gradients, narrow roads and sharp bends are the norm here.
The speed limits in this section are significantly lower than in the previous and following sections - around 35-40 mph (56-64 km/h) - and their strict adherence is even more important than usual.
But interestingly, the mobile phone coverage here is better than in many other areas of the route, e.g. the Pennsylvania Wilds.
German baked goods are rather tasty. In Bavaria they are rather nutritious and varied, just as in the southern neighbour Austria.
Fruit cake is widely available, with apples being sold all year round and cherries and plums being used in the summer.
Many German baked goods contain almonds, hazelnuts or other nuts. Popular cakes often go particularly well with a cup of strong coffee.
If you want to make small, but rich cakes, then try what is called a Berliner, a Pfannkuchen or a Krapfen in different regions.
A curry is a dish that is based on spices and herbs, together with either meat or vegetables.
A curry can be either dry or moist depending on the amount of liquid.
In the interior of northern India and Pakistan, yogurt is usually used in curries; in southern India and some other coastal regions of the subcontinent, coconut milk is usually used.
With a selection of 17,000 islands, Indonesian cuisine is an overarching term that encompasses a wide variety of regional cuisines that can be found throughout the country.
When the term is used without further attributes, it usually refers to food that originates from the central and eastern parts of the main island of Java.

The Javanese cuisine, which is now widespread throughout the island group, offers a wide variety of simply spiced dishes. The Javanese prefer to use peanuts, chilis, sugar (especially Javanese coconut sugar) and a variety of aromatic spices as flavorings.
Spurs are aids for the feet of riders, which hang down on both sides of the saddle.
They give the rider more stability, but there are safety concerns because the rider's feet may get caught in them.
If a rider falls from the horse and gets caught in the stirrup, he can be dragged along if the horse runs. To reduce this risk as much as possible, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First of all, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a flat, rather narrow sole.
In addition, some saddles, in particular English saddles, have safety buckles that allow a stirrup leather to fall as soon as it is pulled backwards by a falling rider.
Cochamó Valley – Chile's most important climbing destination, known as the Yosemite National Park of South America, with a wealth of big granite walls and cliffs.
The summits offer a breathtaking view. Climbers from all over the world discover new routes along the walls, which offer endless possibilities.
Downhill sports such as skiing and snowboarding are popular sports in which you attach skis or a snowboard to your feet and slide down a snow-covered slope.
Skiing is a popular holiday activity with many enthusiasts, sometimes referred to as "ski bunnies", who plan their entire holiday around skiing at a particular location.
The idea of skiing is very old – cave paintings with depictions of skiers go back to 5000 BC!
The origins of skiing as a sport go back at least to the 17th century and in 1861 the first recreational ski club in Australia was opened by Norwegians.
Hiking with a backpack: This activity is also called ski touring or ski hiking.
It resembles alpine touring skiing or mountaineering, but does not necessarily include it, since the latter is carried out in steep terrain and requires much firmer skis and boots.
Consider the ski route as a comparable hiking route.
With good conditions you are able to cover larger distances than on a hike – only very rarely will you be able to reach the speed of a cross country skier without a heavy backpack.

Europe is a relatively small continent, but it has many independent countries. Normally you would have to apply for multiple visas and go through multiple passport checks if you wanted to travel through several countries.
The Schengen area works in this respect somewhat like a country.
As long as you stay in this zone, you can normally cross the border without having to go through passport control again.
You do not have to apply for a visa for each of the Schengen member states, which saves time, money and bureaucracy.
There is no universally accepted definition of what constitutes an antique. Some tax authorities define antiques as objects that are more than 100 years old.
The definition points to geographical differences, where the age limit is lower in places like North America than in Europe.
Handmade products could be described as antique, even though they are younger than similar products from mass production.

Today many Sámi work in modern professions. Tourism is an important source of income in Sápmi, the Sámi region.

Unsettled weather is the collective term for any dangerous weather phenomenon with the potential to cause damage, severe social disruption or the loss of human life.
Weather can occur anywhere in the world and there are different types of it, depending on geography, topography and atmospheric conditions.
Strong winds, hail, excessive rainfall, and forest fires are forms and effects of weather, as are thunderstorms, tornadoes, floods, and whirlwinds.
Regional and seasonal weather phenomena include blizzards, snowstorms, ice storms and dust storms.
Travellers are urged to watch out for any kind of weather that affects their area, as this can affect all travel plans.

A course usually covers all the problems discussed here in much more detail, usually in combination with practical experience.
A course normally lasts between two and five days and includes role-playing, first aid and, in some cases, weapons training.
There are many books and journals about surviving in the wilderness, but only a few publications about war zones.
Passengers who plan to undergo a sex-change operation abroad should ensure that they have valid ID documents for the return journey.

The willingness of foreign governments to recognize these documents is also very different.

Rip currents are the returning current of broken waves at the shore, often at reefs or similar.
Due to the underwater topography, the return flow concentrates in a few deeper areas and a fast current can form there to deep water.
The majority of deaths occur as a result of exhaustion during the attempt to swim against the current, which proves impossible.
If you get out of the current, it's not harder to swim back than it is normally.
Try to get somewhere where you won't be caught again. Alternatively, if you have the skills and if you've been spotted, maybe you should wait for rescue.
The reverse culture shock comes earlier than the culture shock (the honeymoon phase is not as pronounced), lasts longer and can be more serious.
Travelers who find it easy to adapt to the new culture sometimes find it particularly difficult to adapt to their home culture.
When you come back from a stay abroad, you have adapted to a different culture and dropped some of the habits of your home culture.
When you travel abroad for the first time, people are likely to be patient and understanding, because they know that travelers have to adapt to a new country.
It is perhaps not expected that even returning travellers require patience and understanding.

Couriers are well paid for their speedy delivery of things. Often the time is a very important factor in business documents, trade goods or replacement parts for urgent repairs.
On some routes the larger companies use their own aircraft, but on others and with smaller companies there were problems.
If they sent things by air freight, the unloading and customs clearance could take several days on some routes.
The only way to get through it faster was to send it as unaccompanied baggage. The regulations of the airlines do not allow baggage to be sent without a passenger, and that's where you come in.

The capital of Moldova is Chisinau. The local language is Romanian, but many people also speak Russian.
Moldova is a multiethnic republic that has suffered from ethnic conflict.

In 1994, this conflict led to the establishment of the self-proclaimed Republic of Transnistria in eastern Moldova, which has its own government and currency, but is not recognized by any UN member state.
Despite the failure of the political negotiations, the economic relations between these two parts of the Republic of Moldova have been restored.
Christian Orthodoxy is the most important religion in Moldova.
Izmir is the third-largest city in Turkey with a population of about 3.7 million, the second-largest port after Istanbul and a very good transport hub.

In Christianity, Christmas is one of the most important holidays and is celebrated as the birthday of Jesus.
Many of the traditions associated with the festival were adopted by non-believers in Christian and non-Christian countries all over the world.
There is the tradition of spending the Easter night at any open place to see the sunrise.
Of course there are Christian theological explanations for this tradition, but it could just as well be a pre-Christian spring and fertility ritual.

Traditional churches often hold an Easter vigil on Saturday evening, during the Easter weekend, where the celebrations of the communities often start at midnight, where the resurrection of Christ is celebrated.
All the animals that originally arrived on the islands came either by swimming, flying, or by being washed ashore.

Since the first people set foot on the Galapagos Islands, many mammals were introduced, including goats, horses, rats, cats and dogs.

The Japanese work culture is hierarchical and formal, perhaps more so than what Westerners are used to.
Suit jackets are part of the standard business attire, and colleagues address each other by their family names or job titles.
The harmony in the workplace is of decisive importance, with the focus more on the group's performance than on individual praise.
Often employees have to get the approval of their superiors for all decisions they make and they are expected to follow their instructions unconditionally.
